1377620937080705032.text: A once in a generation infrastructure plan must address the needs of residents living in NYCHA and all public housing authorities nationwide.

1377620936162217987.text: That is why I have introduced HR 235, the Public Housing Emergency Response, that eliminates the capital backlog for Public Housing Authorities nationwide and must be included in the Build Back Better Plan.

1377620935277219845.text: NYCHA residents suffer from a consistent lack of hot water, insufficient heat during the winter months, rodent and insect infestations, broken elevators, and widespread and recurring lead and mold problems.

1377620934346080264.text: The estimated capital backlog of public housing authorities nationwide stands at $70 billion. In my home city of New York, estimated needs of the nation’s largest public housing authority—NYCHA--have ballooned to more than $40 Billion.

1377620639977246722.text: Years of disinvestment has left our nation’s public housing system in a state of disrepair. While I appreciate @POTUS's inclusion of $40B to improve public housing infrastructure, it's a minimal investment that doesn’t meet the capital needs of housing authorities nationwide.

This agreement secures:

1341198550219313156.text: So, while I am disappointed in my Republican colleagues and recognize this bill is not ideal or as comprehensive as the Heroes Act—it will provide some much-needed relief to the American people until we can pass a more robust stimulus under the Biden Administration.

1341198549028114433.text: And let me be clear—$600 in direct payments and an additional $300 per week in unemployment is not enough—in fact, it’s just half of the aid that we passed in the CARES Act.

1341198547836923906.text: I just voted in favor of the COVID relief bill in the House because the American people cannot wait another day. It is shameful that it took this long for my colleagues on the other side of the aisle to come to the table.

1341135455530717184.text: As shuttered venues like cultural institutions and movie theaters, that depend on large crowds to survive faced difficulties accessing PPP, this bill creates a new $15 billion dollar grant program to target these establishments that have experienced a dramatic decline in revenue.

1341134975253569538.text: It'll address what we have been hearing on the ground from small businesses—the need for cash infusions through grants. By establishing new guardrails and allocating $20 billion to the EIDL grant program, we are targeting the hardest hit small businesses to receive these grants.

1341134236015861763.text: Our @HouseSmallBiz team has put together a factsheet for more information on how the relief bill will help small businesses. https://t.co/CDGmNJhOuZ

1341134234803695621.text:
It would also set-aside $15 billion for small community banks, small credit unions, and small agricultural
credit institutions; and $15 billion for mission-based community lenders like CDFIs, CDCs, MDIs and microloan intermediaries.

1341134233587363844.text:
It would also create two set-asides for small businesses borrowers with 10 or fewer employees and small
businesses in underserved areas for loans up to $250,000:
o $15 billion set-aside for initial PPP loans; and
o $25 billion set-aside for second PPP loans.

1341134232412975106.text: This bill would ensure PPP funding is targeted to small businesses, not large publicly funded companies by preventing publicly traded companies from receiving PPP funds.

1261402153932910592.text: My floor statement today in support of the #HeroesAct. https://t.co/tOBI0VK2Ze

1261378374653685760.text: This bill is not perfect, but it is necessary. It has important provisions that will help our city and the most vulnerable. I will vote yes. 12/12

1261378373823221760.text: For Puerto Rico this bill would provide $12 billion in direct assistance.11/12

1261378372862570496.text: It provides badly needed fiscal relief for hard hit states and localities. New York State will receive $34 billion in fiscal relief and the City will receive $17 billion.  An important start. 10/12

1261378371897839617.text: It also provides $10 billion in grants for #SmallBusinesses.  9/12

1261378370618589186.text: The bill sets aside 25% of existing funds – about $30 billion – to go firms with fewer than 10 employees – prioritizing some of our smallest businesses. 8/12

1261378369649881094.text: For #SmallBusinesses the bill improves #PPP. It allows a longer period for use of the loans, fixing the “eight week” issue we’ve heard about. 7/12

1261378368647225345.text: It sets forth a strategic plan for testing and contract tracing. Only with testing & tracing can we control this virus and, eventually, fully reopen our economy. 6/12

1261378367535767552.text: It includes hazard pay for essential workers on the front lines of this crisis. They are the true heroes of this crisis and the Heroes Act gives them fairer compensation & #PPE 5/12

1261378366151766016.text: Under the bill economic stimulus payments will now be available to those with Individual Taxpayer Identification Numbers (#ITIN), so that undocumented communities can receive these payments. This will also be retroactive. 4/12

1261378365111615496.text: It provides a second round of more substantial economic stimulus payments consisting of $1,200 per family member, and up to $6,000 per household to ease the financial burden that many are experiencing due to #COVID19. 3/12

1261378323764166658.text: The bill boosts funds for Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (#SNAP) by 15%. In my district, I’ve seen lines at local food banks. Families need this assistance. 2/12

1261378322723790849.text: The #HeroesAct, the #coronavirus bill we are voting on today, contains several important priorities I fought for. While the bill could go further, I’m pleased with much of what we secured. 1/12
